results.title: Be it ever so humble
results.creator_credit: Ron Iddon, John Sparkes and ABC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
Shot in Queensland, this film examines the development in styles of houses in Australia, from the slab hut to the contemporary brick house. Suitable for Upper Secondary-Tertiary level students.

results.title: Forest and range
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Environment in crisis: problems of conservation”.
Presents “multiple use programmes” in which American forests are used for produce in addition to recreation. This program juxtaposes the need for food, lumber and recreation against the desire to retain undeveloped areas.

results.title: Air
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Environment in crisis: problems of conservation”.
Studies the affects of air pollution on health and property. Natural pollutants existed long before man but harmful pollution did not start until the start of the Industrial Revolutions. This film explains what has caused man-made pollution and what is being done to solve the problem through technological and legislative controls.

results.title: A Land fit for heroes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
Examines the harsh reality that lay behind the concept of parcelling out plots of land for soldiers returning from both the first and second world wars. Uses archival footage, interviews and old radio broadcasts. Reporter - Ron Iddon. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Snatch [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Guy Ritchie, Matthew Vaughn and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Guy Ritchie’s second feature follows on seamlessly from his first: the music video/caper movie, “Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels”. It’s cast - peppered with Hollywood stars Benicio Del Toro, Dennis Farina and Brad Pitt - portray a crowd of London small-timers torturing, mutilating and wise-cracking their way across Ritchie’s home territory: ludicrous plots, racial stereotypes and groovy pop music, all in the name of derisively good fun. If “Lock, Stock” was an escapade into guilt-free sick violence, then “Snatch” is exactly the same.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Guy Ritchie, Matthew Vaughn and Columbia Pictures

results.title: Right Through the Shearing Time
results.creator_credit: John Maybe, Trevor Stockley and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
This film features sheep shearing at Moree and Yass, in New South Wales, and provides extensive information about this distinctive Australian industry. It also shows the life of the seasonal workers who are employed in this rural activity.

results.title: Looking Ahead
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
The launching of the Landsat satellite in 1972 began the extensive and detailed monitoring of remote landscapes. Using satellite data the South Australian Government is currently conducting a full-scale ecological survey of the Lake Everard area. It is hoped to extend the program to cover the whole country within 25 years.

results.title: Dingo country
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
A fence almost 6,000 miles long stretches from South Australia to Queensland and attempts to separate the dingo from the sheep. The dingoes are vigorously hunted and killed, but the film presents the view that man must learn to acept the dingo.

results.title: Mulga Bill's Bicycle Band
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
Mulga Bill’s Bicycle Band, a group of musicians from Melbourne, play adaptations of English and Irish folk music. This episode of A Big Country follows the band as they rescue their music from the abstractions of television studios and return it to the living ambience of country halls and hotels.

results.title: Snowy Mountain riders
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
In the Snowy Mountains of southern New South Wales, near Jindabyne, there is to be a horse meeting to honour the first settlers of the district. The film shows the rounding-up and breaking-in of wild brumbies for the picnic race meeting and comments on the change in the district over the years. Narrated by Ron Iddon.
